items.label: lem-exchangeability
items.title: Exchangeability of the N-Particle QSD
items.content:
217: :label: lem-exchangeability
218: 
219: The unique N-particle QSD $\nu_N^{QSD}$ is an exchangeable measure on the product space $\Omega^N$. That is, for any permutation $\sigma$ of the indices $\{1, \ldots, N\}$ and any measurable set $A \subseteq \Omega^N$,
220: 
221: $$
222: \nu_N^{QSD}(\{(z_1, \ldots, z_N) \in A\}) = \nu_N^{QSD}(\{(z_{\sigma(1)}, \ldots, z_{\sigma(N)}) \in A\})
items.raw_directive:
214: #### **Lemma A.1: Exchangeability of the N-Particle QSD**
215: 
216: :::{prf:lemma} Exchangeability of the N-Particle QSD
217: :label: lem-exchangeability
218: 
219: The unique N-particle QSD $\nu_N^{QSD}$ is an exchangeable measure on the product space $\Omega^N$. That is, for any permutation $\sigma$ of the indices $\{1, \ldots, N\}$ and any measurable set $A \subseteq \Omega^N$,
220: 
221: $$
222: \nu_N^{QSD}(\{(z_1, \ldots, z_N) \in A\}) = \nu_N^{QSD}(\{(z_{\sigma(1)}, \ldots, z_{\sigma(N)}) \in A\})
223:

items.label: lem-empirical-convergence
items.title: Weak Convergence of the Empirical Companion Measure
items.content:
239: :label: lem-empirical-convergence
240: 
241: Let $\{N_k\}$ be any subsequence such that $\mu_{N_k} \rightharpoonup \mu_\infty$. For a configuration $S_{N_k} = (z_1, \ldots, z_{N_k})$ drawn from $\nu_{N_k}^{QSD}$, define the empirical companion measure
242: 
243: $$
244: \mu_{N_k-1}^{\text{comp}}(S_{N_k}) := \frac{1}{N_k-1} \sum_{j=2}^{N_k} \delta_{z_j}
245: 
246: $$
247: 
248: Then for $\nu_{N_k}^{QSD}$-almost every sequence of configurations, as $k \to \infty$,
249: 
250: $$
251: \mu_{N_k-1}^{\text{comp}}(S_{N_k}) \rightharpoonup \mu_\infty \quad \text{weakly in } \mathcal{P}(\Omega)
items.raw_directive:
236: #### **Lemma A.2: Weak Convergence of the Empirical Companion Measure**
237: 
238: :::{prf:lemma} Weak Convergence of the Empirical Companion Measure
239: :label: lem-empirical-convergence
240: 
241: Let $\{N_k\}$ be any subsequence such that $\mu_{N_k} \rightharpoonup \mu_\infty$. For a configuration $S_{N_k} = (z_1, \ldots, z_{N_k})$ drawn from $\nu_{N_k}^{QSD}$, define the empirical companion measure
242: 
243: $$
244: \mu_{N_k-1}^{\text{comp}}(S_{N_k}) := \frac{1}{N_k-1} \sum_{j=2}^{N_k} \delta_{z_j}
245: 
246: $$
247: 
248: Then for $\nu_{N_k}^{QSD}$-almost every sequence of configurations, as $k \to \infty$,
249: 
250: $$
251: \mu_{N_k-1}^{\text{comp}}(S_{N_k}) \rightharpoonup \mu_\infty \quad \text{weakly in } \mathcal{P}(\Omega)
252:

items.label: lem-reward-continuity
items.title: Continuity of the Reward Moments
items.content:
281: :label: lem-reward-continuity
282: 
283: The reward moment functionals $\mu_R[\cdot]$ and $\sigma_R^2[\cdot]$ are continuous with respect to weak convergence of measures. That is, if $\{\mu_k\}$ converges weakly to $\mu_\infty$, then
284: 
285: $$
286: \lim_{k \to \infty} \mu_R[\mu_k] = \mu_R[\mu_\infty] \quad \text{and} \quad \lim_{k \to \infty} \sigma_R^2[\mu_k] = \sigma_R^2[\mu_\infty]
items.raw_directive:
278: #### **Lemma B.1: Continuity of the Reward Moments**
279: 
280: :::{prf:lemma} Continuity of the Reward Moments
281: :label: lem-reward-continuity
282: 
283: The reward moment functionals $\mu_R[\cdot]$ and $\sigma_R^2[\cdot]$ are continuous with respect to weak convergence of measures. That is, if $\{\mu_k\}$ converges weakly to $\mu_\infty$, then
284: 
285: $$
286: \lim_{k \to \infty} \mu_R[\mu_k] = \mu_R[\mu_\infty] \quad \text{and} \quad \lim_{k \to \infty} \sigma_R^2[\mu_k] = \sigma_R^2[\mu_\infty]
287:

items.label: lem-distance-continuity
items.title: Continuity of the Distance Moments
items.content:
310: :label: lem-distance-continuity
311: 
312: The distance moment functionals $\mu_D[\cdot]$ and $\sigma_D^2[\cdot]$ are continuous with respect to weak convergence of measures. That is, if $\{\mu_k\}$ converges weakly to $\mu_\infty$, then
313: 
314: $$
315: \lim_{k \to \infty} \mu_D[\mu_k] = \mu_D[\mu_\infty] \quad \text{and} \quad \lim_{k \to \infty} \sigma_D^2[\mu_k] = \sigma_D^2[\mu_\infty]
items.raw_directive:
307: #### **Lemma B.2: Continuity of the Distance Moments**
308: 
309: :::{prf:lemma} Continuity of the Distance Moments
310: :label: lem-distance-continuity
311: 
312: The distance moment functionals $\mu_D[\cdot]$ and $\sigma_D^2[\cdot]$ are continuous with respect to weak convergence of measures. That is, if $\{\mu_k\}$ converges weakly to $\mu_\infty$, then
313: 
314: $$
315: \lim_{k \to \infty} \mu_D[\mu_k] = \mu_D[\mu_\infty] \quad \text{and} \quad \lim_{k \to \infty} \sigma_D^2[\mu_k] = \sigma_D^2[\mu_\infty]
316:

items.label: lem-uniform-integrability
items.title: Uniform Integrability and Interchange of Limits
items.content:
365: :label: lem-uniform-integrability
366: 
367: Let $\phi \in C_c^\infty(\Omega)$ be a smooth, compactly supported test function. The sequence of integrands
368: 
369: $$
370: \left\{ \mathcal{L}_{N_k} \phi(z_1) \right\}_{k=1}^\infty
371: 
372: $$
373: 
374: is uniformly integrable with respect to the measures $\{\nu_{N_k}^{QSD}\}$. Consequently, for any convergent subsequence $\mu_{N_k} \rightharpoonup \mu_\infty$,
375: 
376: $$
377: \lim_{k \to \infty} \mathbb{E}_{\nu_{N_k}^{QSD}}[\mathcal{L}_{N_k} \phi(z_1)] = \mathbb{E}_{\mu_\infty}\left[\lim_{k \to \infty} \mathbb{E}^{(N_k)}_{\text{comp}}[\mathcal{L}_{N_k} \phi(z_1) \mid z_1]\right]
378: 
379: $$
items.raw_directive:
362: #### **Lemma C.1: Uniform Integrability and Interchange of Limits**
363: 
364: :::{prf:lemma} Uniform Integrability and Interchange of Limits
365: :label: lem-uniform-integrability
366: 
367: Let $\phi \in C_c^\infty(\Omega)$ be a smooth, compactly supported test function. The sequence of integrands
368: 
369: $$
370: \left\{ \mathcal{L}_{N_k} \phi(z_1) \right\}_{k=1}^\infty
371: 
372: $$
373: 
374: is uniformly integrable with respect to the measures $\{\nu_{N_k}^{QSD}\}$. Consequently, for any convergent subsequence $\mu_{N_k} \rightharpoonup \mu_\infty$,
375: 
376: $$
377: \lim_{k \to \infty} \mathbb{E}_{\nu_{N_k}^{QSD}}[\mathcal{L}_{N_k} \phi(z_1)] = \mathbb{E}_{\mu_\infty}\left[\lim_{k \to \infty} \mathbb{E}^{(N_k)}_{\text{comp}}[\mathcal{L}_{N_k} \phi(z_1) \mid z_1]\right]
378: 
379: $$
380:

items.label: lem-boundary-convergence
items.title: Convergence of Boundary Death and Revival
items.content:
414: :label: lem-boundary-convergence
415: 
416: Let $\{N_k\}$ be any subsequence such that $\mu_{N_k} \rightharpoonup \mu_\infty$. The discrete boundary death and revival mechanism of the N-particle system converges to the continuous interior-killing-and-revival operators. For any smooth test function $\phi \in C_c^\infty(\Omega)$:
417: 
418: $$
419: \lim_{k \to \infty} \mathbb{E}_{\nu_{N_k}^{QSD}}[\mathcal{L}_{\text{boundary}, N_k} \phi(z_1)]
420: = \int_{\Omega} \left(-c(z)\rho_0(z) + B[\rho_0, m_{d,\infty}](z)\right) \phi(z) \, dz
421: 
422: $$
items.raw_directive:
411: #### **Lemma C.2: Convergence of the Boundary Death and Revival Mechanism**
412: 
413: :::{prf:lemma} Convergence of Boundary Death and Revival
414: :label: lem-boundary-convergence
415: 
416: Let $\{N_k\}$ be any subsequence such that $\mu_{N_k} \rightharpoonup \mu_\infty$. The discrete boundary death and revival mechanism of the N-particle system converges to the continuous interior-killing-and-revival operators. For any smooth test function $\phi \in C_c^\infty(\Omega)$:
417: 
418: $$
419: \lim_{k \to \infty} \mathbb{E}_{\nu_{N_k}^{QSD}}[\mathcal{L}_{\text{boundary}, N_k} \phi(z_1)]
420: = \int_{\Omega} \left(-c(z)\rho_0(z) + B[\rho_0, m_{d,\infty}](z)\right) \phi(z) \, dz
421: 
422: $$
423:

items.label: lem-uniqueness-self-mapping
items.title: Self-Mapping Property of the Solution Operator
items.section: ## **5. Uniqueness of the Weak Solution via Contraction Mapping**
items.raw_directive:
935: A stationary solution is a fixed point of the solution operator $\mathcal{T}: \mathcal{P} \to \mathcal{P}$.
936: 
937: :::{prf:lemma} Self-Mapping Property of the Solution Operator
938: :label: lem-uniqueness-self-mapping
939:

_registry_context.section_id: ## **5. Uniqueness of the Weak Solution via Contraction Mapping**

items.label: lem-uniqueness-lipschitz-moments
items.title: Lipschitz Continuity of Moment Functionals
items.content:
1065: :label: lem-uniqueness-lipschitz-moments
1066: 
1067: The moment functionals $\mu_R[\cdot], \sigma_R[\cdot], \mu_D[\cdot], \sigma_D[\cdot]$ are Lipschitz continuous from $H^1_w(\Omega)$ to $\mathbb{R}$. That is, there exist constants $L_{\mu}, L_{\sigma} > 0$ such that for all $\rho_1, \rho_2 \in \mathcal{P}$:
1068: 
1069: $$
1070: |\mu_R[\rho_1] - \mu_R[\rho_2]| \le L_{\mu} \|\rho_1 - \rho_2\|_{H^1_w}
1071: 
1072: $$
items.section: ## **5. Uniqueness of the Weak Solution via Contraction Mapping**
items.raw_directive:
1062: :::
1063: 
1064: :::{prf:lemma} Lipschitz Continuity of Moment Functionals
1065: :label: lem-uniqueness-lipschitz-moments
1066: 
1067: The moment functionals $\mu_R[\cdot], \sigma_R[\cdot], \mu_D[\cdot], \sigma_D[\cdot]$ are Lipschitz continuous from $H^1_w(\Omega)$ to $\mathbb{R}$. That is, there exist constants $L_{\mu}, L_{\sigma} > 0$ such that for all $\rho_1, \rho_2 \in \mathcal{P}$:
1068: 
1069: $$
1070: |\mu_R[\rho_1] - \mu_R[\rho_2]| \le L_{\mu} \|\rho_1 - \rho_2\|_{H^1_w}
1071: 
1072: $$
1073:

_registry_context.section_id: ## **5. Uniqueness of the Weak Solution via Contraction Mapping**

items.label: lem-uniqueness-fixed-point-bounded
items.title: Fixed Points Lie in a Bounded Ball
items.content:
1110: :label: lem-uniqueness-fixed-point-bounded
1111: 
1112: Any fixed point $\rho^* \in \mathcal{P}$ of the solution operator $\mathcal{T}$ satisfies a uniform bound in the $H^1_w$ norm. Specifically, there exists a radius $R_* < \infty$, independent of the particular fixed point, such that:
1113: 
1114: $$
1115: \|\rho^*\|_{H^1_w} \leq R_*
items.section: ## **5. Uniqueness of the Weak Solution via Contraction Mapping**
items.raw_directive:
1107: :::
1108: 
1109: :::{prf:lemma} Fixed Points Lie in a Bounded Ball
1110: :label: lem-uniqueness-fixed-point-bounded
1111: 
1112: Any fixed point $\rho^* \in \mathcal{P}$ of the solution operator $\mathcal{T}$ satisfies a uniform bound in the $H^1_w$ norm. Specifically, there exists a radius $R_* < \infty$, independent of the particular fixed point, such that:
1113: 
1114: $$
1115: \|\rho^*\|_{H^1_w} \leq R_*
1116:

items.label: lem-uniqueness-lipschitz-fitness-potential
items.title: Lipschitz Continuity of the Fitness Potential
items.content:
1244: :label: lem-uniqueness-lipschitz-fitness-potential
1245: 
1246: The fitness potential operator $\rho \mapsto V[\rho]$ is Lipschitz continuous from $\mathcal{P}$ to $L^\infty(\Omega)$. That is, there exists $L_V > 0$ such that:
1247: 
1248: $$
1249: \|V[\rho_1] - V[\rho_2]\|_{L^\infty} \le L_V \|\rho_1 - \rho_2\|_{H^1_w}
items.section: ## **5. Uniqueness of the Weak Solution via Contraction Mapping**
items.raw_directive:
1241: :::
1242: 
1243: :::{prf:lemma} Lipschitz Continuity of the Fitness Potential
1244: :label: lem-uniqueness-lipschitz-fitness-potential
1245: 
1246: The fitness potential operator $\rho \mapsto V[\rho]$ is Lipschitz continuous from $\mathcal{P}$ to $L^\infty(\Omega)$. That is, there exists $L_V > 0$ such that:
1247: 
1248: $$
1249: \|V[\rho_1] - V[\rho_2]\|_{L^\infty} \le L_V \|\rho_1 - \rho_2\|_{H^1_w}
1250:

items.label: lem-uniqueness-lipschitz-cloning-operator
items.title: Local Lipschitz Continuity of the Cloning Operator
items.content:
1282: :label: lem-uniqueness-lipschitz-cloning-operator
1283: 
1284: The cloning operator $S: \mathcal{P} \to H^1_w(\Omega)$ is **locally Lipschitz continuous**. For any $R > 0$, on the ball $\mathcal{P}_R := \mathcal{P} \cap \{\rho : \|\rho\|_{H^1_w} \leq R\}$, there exists a Lipschitz constant $L_S(R)$ such that for all $\rho_1, \rho_2 \in \mathcal{P}_R$:
1285: 
1286: $$
1287: \|S[\rho_1] - S[\rho_2]\|_{H^1_w} \le L_S(R) \|\rho_1 - \rho_2\|_{H^1_w}
1288: 
1289: $$
items.section: ## **5. Uniqueness of the Weak Solution via Contraction Mapping**
items.raw_directive:
1279: :::
1280: 
1281: :::{prf:lemma} Local Lipschitz Continuity of the Cloning Operator
1282: :label: lem-uniqueness-lipschitz-cloning-operator
1283: 
1284: The cloning operator $S: \mathcal{P} \to H^1_w(\Omega)$ is **locally Lipschitz continuous**. For any $R > 0$, on the ball $\mathcal{P}_R := \mathcal{P} \cap \{\rho : \|\rho\|_{H^1_w} \leq R\}$, there exists a Lipschitz constant $L_S(R)$ such that for all $\rho_1, \rho_2 \in \mathcal{P}_R$:
1285: 
1286: $$
1287: \|S[\rho_1] - S[\rho_2]\|_{H^1_w} \le L_S(R) \|\rho_1 - \rho_2\|_{H^1_w}
1288: 
1289: $$
1290:

items.label: lem-uniqueness-scaling-hypoelliptic-constant
items.title: Scaling of $C_{\text{hypo}}$ with Diffusion Strength
items.content:
1645: :label: lem-uniqueness-scaling-hypoelliptic-constant
1646: 
1647: The constant $C_{\text{hypo}}$ from Theorem [](#thm-uniqueness-hypoelliptic-regularity) satisfies the scaling estimate:
1648: 
1649: $$
1650: C_{\text{hypo}} \sim \frac{1}{\min(\sigma_v^2 \gamma, C)}
1651: 
1652: $$
1653: 
1654: In particular, for $C$ fixed and $\sigma_v^2$ sufficiently large:
1655: 
1656: $$
1657: C_{\text{hypo}} \lesssim \frac{1}{\sigma_v^2 \gamma}
items.section: ## **5. Uniqueness of the Weak Solution via Contraction Mapping**
items.raw_directive:
1642: #### **C.4. Scaling of the Hypoelliptic Constant**
1643: 
1644: :::{prf:lemma} Scaling of $C_{\text{hypo}}$ with Diffusion Strength
1645: :label: lem-uniqueness-scaling-hypoelliptic-constant
1646: 
1647: The constant $C_{\text{hypo}}$ from Theorem [](#thm-uniqueness-hypoelliptic-regularity) satisfies the scaling estimate:
1648: 
1649: $$
1650: C_{\text{hypo}} \sim \frac{1}{\min(\sigma_v^2 \gamma, C)}
1651: 
1652: $$
1653: 
1654: In particular, for $C$ fixed and $\sigma_v^2$ sufficiently large:
1655: 
1656: $$
1657: C_{\text{hypo}} \lesssim \frac{1}{\sigma_v^2 \gamma}
1658:
